request_pathways.name: Authorization to Release and Disclose Patient Information (Printable Form)
Fax submission to Health Information Department

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient uses a generic HIPAA authorization form for all record releases, with a 'Personal Use' checkbox to indicate self-access; a HIPAA-compliant JotForm online alternative is also available.

red_flags: Sensitive information (chemical dependency, behavioral health) defaults to release unless patient actively opts out by initialing — concerning under 42 CFR Part 2
Outdated form versions (2015, 2018) remain publicly accessible and could be found via search engines
bright_spots: Parenthetical plain-language guidance on section headers (e.g., 'WHO HAS THE INFORMATION YOU WANT RELEASED?')
HIPAA-compliant JotForm online submission available as alternative to printable PDF
Current form eliminated SSN collection and witness requirements present in earlier versions
'Routine Record Sets' checkbox with definition helps patients understand standard records requests

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation or a simple search — Patient Forms page is one click from main nav, and web search returns direct PDF links; minor deduction for outdated versions still accessible via search engines.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: Mostly digital with one gap — the PDF form itself has zero fillable fields (print-and-fill), but the organization offers a HIPAA-compliant JotForm online alternative providing a fully digital submission pathway, plus fax submission for the PDF.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — clean single-page layout with helpful parenthetical plain-language headers, logical section flow, and reasonable field count; minor issues include dense authorization language, 'Guardian' misspelled, and ambiguous opt-out initialing for sensitive records.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — generic HIPAA authorization form with 'Personal Use' checkbox accommodates self-requests, but no dedicated patient access pathway, no mention of HIPAA Right of Access, and patient must navigate a from/to structure designed for third-party transfers.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities but nothing that would materially impede a patient — no notarization, no witness, fax available, reasonable expiration; minor concerns include default-release model for 42 CFR Part 2 substance abuse records, ambiguous 'present' revocation language, and no fee disclosure.

overall.summary: Riverwood provides a functional records request experience with easy findability and both printable and online submission options, but relies on a generic authorization form that doesn't differentiate patient self-access from third-party release.
